captions.text: [Intro]

It's a notion that's been propagated by movies,
magazines, and motivational speakers and repeated

by well-meaning folks and shysters alike.
They tell you that you're only using 10% of

your brain. If you're only able to access
a fraction of your brain-power, just imagine

what you could do if you tapped into all that
unused potential!

Read other people's thoughts, play the stock
market, crush cans with your mind, and levitate.

Not to rain on your brain parade, but that
10% stuff is so far off that it would be laughable

if it weren't so widespread, and I kinda can't
believe I'm still talking about it!

So like many myths, it's hard to pinpoint
exactly where it began. There's no definitive

source, though some have linked it back to
the American psychologist William James and

even Albert Einstein, who both suggested,
in so many words, that we were only using
part of our mental potential.

But the fact is, we is pretty much every part
of our brains. A lot of it is active most

of the time, whether you're reading a book,
or listening to music, or walking around town
or even sleeping.

How can we be so sure? For one thing neuro-imaging
techniques like PET scans and MRIs actually

let us see the brain in action. These images
show as that nearly every region of the brain

lights up during even simple tasks, like walking
and talking.

While we don't use all of our brain at once,
just like we don't engage every single muscle

at the same time, those scans prove that over
the course of any given day you use just about
all of your brain.

It also stands to reason that if 90% of your
brain was useless, you could remove large

portions of it, as you might an appendix or
tonsil, and carry on as usual.

Brain damage and disease wouldn't be as much
of a concern if only 10% of the organ was

actually functional. But in reality, there
isn't a single area of the brain that can

be damaged or diseased without resulting in
some kind of physical or mental consequence,
small or big.

You may have heard of the case of Phineas
Gage, the 19th-century railroad worker, who

wound up with a spike through his head because
of an accident. It didn't actually stay in

his head, it went all the way through and
then kept going for quite a while. It didn't

kill him, somewhat surprisingly, and he still
had his memories and his skills. But many

of his friends reported that he had changed
personalities. Now we don't actually know

a ton about Gage, because a lot of people
used him to try and prove a lot of different

of points over the years, but there's little
doubt that you can have a rod go through your
brain and not have some things messed with.

Then there's Clive Wearing, the British pianist,
who had a viral infection that destroyed his

hippocampus, the part of the brain that controls
the storage of memories. As a result he's

no longer able to recognize anyone but his
wife, and he can't retain a memory for more
than 30 seconds at a time.

Every part of your brain has a function, and
you need it in order to keep being you.

And finally, we know that our brains are working
all the time because we have to constantly

feed them, literally. The average human brain
accounts for about 3% of a person's bodyweight,

but it demands at least 20% of the body's
energy to keep all those neurons firing. We're

talking hundreds of food calories every day
just so your brain can remind your heart to

beat, or help you solve for X, or remember
where you left your phone. Our constant need

for food, especially foods rich in fats and
sugars, has a lot to do with our brains. And

it wouldn't make much evolutionary sense for
us to expend so much energy feeding a useless,
wet lump.

So in the end, while telekinesis would be
pretty awesome, our brains are already capable

of truly incredible things. In fact, if anything,
we only understand a fraction of what's going

on up there, so instead of insulting its function,
be thankful for all that your brain does,
which is more than you know.

Thanks for watching this SciShow Dose. If
you'd like to help us keep informing people

of when they're wrong, you can go to subbable.com/scishow
and become a contributing member. And if you

want to just keep getting smarter with us,
pleeeease go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe,
and rate 5 stars.

title: Do I Only Use 10% of My Brain?

comments.text: People did assume that the world was flat for awhile.﻿

comments.text:
Of course you don't use 10% of your brain power, what would be the point in 
your body producing organic material it doesn't need/use, you use your 
whole brain for different tasks and one of the reasons some believe that 
you don't use all of your brain power is that if you were to become blind 
your other senses become stronger to try and make up for the loss, so why 
do the senses increase strength after the sense of sight is lost and not 
just use the senses to their maximum all the time?﻿

comments.text:
Really the only reason you people will never know everything and know if 
you actually use 10% of your brain or its potential is because your too 
obsessed with wanting to know. Being human is the one thing that keeps us 
human. We have so many obstacles that keep us from every knowing more than 
we know now. Such as pain, love, and wanting to learn. If you spent less 
time trying to learn something and just did it then you could actually do 
it. But being human we will always be wondering how we do the things we do. 
So if you have a Rubix cube and you want to solve it without learning and 
just did it, first you would have to get rid of the fact that you want to 
know how to do it. We as humans use diffrent measurements to learn but they 
don't exist. Say 1+1=2 but really it will never equal 2 because the only 
real measurement that exist is TIME. Time is the only reason we are here. 
Before you say "No, G-d is the one who created everything and TIME". It 
took him time to make the earth and the heavens. Hopefully this made you 
understand even though we won't really understand it. Feel free to 
subscribe to my channel(which is not related to this comment what so ever) 
but you do not have to. Thank you for reading. ﻿

comments.text:
One of my college professors believes this. She said that we only used 
about 3% - 10% of our brains and I was like... Wtf? I had read about 4 
different articles that debunked this myth and I had watched this video soo 
I knew (know) it's bullshit, although before reading/watching them I did 
believe in the myth too though. Now, the sad part isn't the fact that she 
believes (And many of the students who commented in class which basically 
supported this myth), the sad part is the fact that she studied and 
graduated from Harvard. She is a licensed psychologist that graduated from 
a really prestigious university and she believes this... And yeah, I don't 
expect people to not make mistakes, we all do, but is it so hard to look 
for two or three articles, videos and/or books about this topic to see if 
it is true or not? I mean, you are teaching students and unintentionally 
spreading ignorance at the same time, like come on...﻿

comments.author: Skarmx2

comments.text:
The cerebral cortex (the nerve centre of the brain itself), happens to be 
several times larger than is necessary for the comparatively small amount 
of thought and action that we have managed to achieve up to now. On the 
purely physical level, we have the mental equipment of a race thousands, or 
even millions of years more advanced than our own.
     There is seldom anything found in nature that does not have a reason 
for being there, so why are we possessed of a mental ‘engine’ that seldom 
gets up to the top speed of its first gear? Are we getting ready for some 
spectacular leap forward when we learn how to press the right levers and 
buttons, or did we once know the capabilities of this mighty engine but 
have now forgotten them?
     Is there a broken link between the ferreting, detail-ridden, 
critically anxious conscious mind - so necessary to our ordinary 
functioning - and this vaster, more potent psyche that is sometimes 
revealed?
Did a cybernetic relationship between the two once exist in which the 
conscious fed its logically assessed information to the other part which 
then provided the power to solve the problems?
     If so, can it be re-forged? Ought it to be?
Oliver Cambren﻿

comments.text:
I think maybe the correct usage would be "mental potential" not "brain 
power." Yes, we use ALL of our brain, but most humans can't achieve more 
than 10% of its POTENTIAL to do more. Not things like levitate, or read 
other people's minds, or have psychic future telling powers, but rather 
better memory, the ability to recognize patterns easier, puzzle soving 
ability, hearing, more vocabulary and such. The average human of this era 
does not have a very wide vocabulary, Americans especially (no offense, I'm 
an American myself), and most people can not remember things as well as 
others can. Not to mention the ability to solve puzzles. I can't solve a 
Rubik's Cube, but I can solve riddles, games, and crosswords fairly easily. 
I guess my point is is that we don't use the full processing power of our 
brains, the potential to do great things with your brain. But then again, 
there are people who have unlocked the secrets and have done amazing 
things, like Einstein and Hawking.﻿

comments.author: fiercedietyfan

comments.text:
I think what's meant by the saying is that "you can only *control* 10% of 
your brain", and somehow people interpreted it wrong. What the original 
sayers meant is that you can only control the part that thinks, the part 
that controls the outside muscles, the part that controls your vocal cords 
etc... Just not the part that makes your heart function or the part that 
controls your lungs. I'm no biologist by any mean, but what they're trying 
to say that if you controlled 100% of your brain, you'd be completely aware 
of all your body and every neuron in your head and would be able to make it 
do what you want, ordering flesh cells to start dividing and regenerating 
lost parts of your flesh and maybe even lost limbs, making an abnormal bump 
form in any part of your body resulting in an extra body part, changing 
your body composition, ordering neurons to stop alert you and resulting in 
feeling pain, and maybe even dividing yourself if it gets to such a point.
And what people understood from the myth is that 90% of your brain is not 
functioning, forgetting that the brain orders all your vital organs.

And if you think about it, your brain is amazing. The way it figures out 
how far something is from lens focusing and eye angles (basically 
Trigonometry), The way it approximates stuff, the way it's multi-functional 
and more powerful than what the human can make. Your brains knows 
trigonometry and you don't (i.e. the closer the eye to the nose the closer 
the object focused on is, assuming it's directly in front of you). Maybe if 
somehow, your intelligent, comprehending brain and the other brain that 
controls everything unite, maybe you could do a lot of stuff.

I apologize for anyone with knowledge that wants to smack me at the moment, 
but that's how i interpreted the whole thing.﻿
comments.author: BuPh GoukuSatsu

comments.text:
This brings up a question: If your brain ever was so powerful, wouldn't it 
be deadly? Too much nerve reception can result in too much pain and 
pressure for ANY subtle change in environment; too much (conscious) control 
of cell growth can lead to irregular growth since it most likely will not 
be consistent; super enhanced nerves in your eye may be too receptive to 
light and could be blinding; too much energy...etc.

Most importantly, you'll probably stay starving burning a huge amount of 
calories per time interval just to keep your brain alive performing all 
those functions.

comments.author: XxtrollsniperXx

comments.text:
more proof: "he The Word [Jesus] was God” and “the Word became flesh” (John 
1:1, 14). These verses clearly indicate that Jesus is God in the flesh. 
Acts 20:28 tells us, “Be shepherds of the church of God, which he bought 
with his own blood.” Who bought the church with His own blood? Jesus 
Christ. And this same verse declares that God purchased His church with His 
own blood. Therefore, Jesus is God!

Thomas the disciple declared concerning Jesus, “My Lord and my God” (John 
20:28). Jesus does not correct him. Titus 2:13 encourages us to wait for 
the coming of our God and Savior, Jesus Christ (see also 2 Peter 1:1). In 
Hebrews 1:8, the Father declares of Jesus, “But about the Son he says, 
‘Your throne, O God, will last forever and ever, and righteousness will be 
the scepter of your kingdom.’” The Father refers to Jesus as “O God,” 
indicating that Jesus is indeed God.

In Revelation, an angel instructed the apostle John to only worship God 
(Revelation 19:10). Several times in Scripture Jesus receives worship 
(Matthew 2:11; 14:33; 28:9, 17; Luke 24:52; John 9:38). He never rebukes 
people for worshiping Him. If Jesus were not God, He would have told people 
to not worship Him, just as the angel in Revelation did. There are many 
other passages of Scripture that argue for Jesus’ deity.

The most important reason that Jesus has to be God is that, if He is not 
God, His death would not have been sufficient to pay the penalty for the 
sins of the world (1 John 2:2). A created being, which Jesus would be if He 
were not God, could not pay the infinite penalty required for sin against 
an infinite God. Only God could pay such an infinite penalty. Only God 
could take on the sins of the world (2 Corinthians 5:21), die, and be 
resurrected, proving His victory over sin and death.
comments.author: XxtrollsniperXx

comments.author: mike knite

comments.text:
Let me tell you something and think about this. The video you just watch 
explained how are brain is used but what if I were to rephrase the 
question? What if we only CONTROL 10% of our brain? For example, In the 
Scholary Articles at the very back of our brain, we have that pain 
receptors. (Be Sensible) If I asked you to dip your bare hand in boiling 
water for 10 seconds, I know for fact no normal human being could resist 
the pain. We cant control that part of our brain. There are many other 
examples, like the part of our brain that keeps our heart pumping, the 
hippocampus which store our memory. The part of your brain that controls 
reflexes, the part of the brain that interprets soundwaves from your ear 
and many more. I leave you with a question. We may use 10% of our brain, 
but do we control it?﻿

comments.text:
what you think about the saying " you only use 10% of your brain " is a 
misconception. what it's saying is that we don't use it's full potential. 
Our memory system erases memories every day even though if we used 75-80% 
of our brain we can be like computers remembering every moment and every 
detail of our lives since we were 2-3 years old. We would also be a lot 
quicker, smarter, and more creative if we used 75-80% of our brain, but 
there would probably be incidences where someones brain just shuts down and 
dies because his hard and lungs quit working. Let's say a pro football 
player goes back to high school football yes he's going to use his running, 
dodging, catching, and tackling skills, but do you think he'll try to juke 
out a kid half his size that's coming up on him? no he'll prob be going 
half fast if a kid half his size come up he'll just lower his shoulder and 
keep running. the brain pretty much only uses as much as it needs and then 
some. and that's probably why your ass should make another video cuz ur ass 
got it all wrong﻿

already enlightened most of us just don't realize it". Or to put it in my 
own more mundane words, being multi orgasmic isn't something that requires 
special genes or a different use of the body, all that is required is a 
change in focus/awareness.
The implicit(erroneous) assumption in how much of our brains we use is that 
consciousness is dependent on our brain. What if man really is created in 
the image of God and such divine consciousness requires not 100% use of our 
brain, but only a different awareness/consciousness?
Besides it's said that people that are in the flow actually use less of 
their brain and yet function much better﻿
